CountryData.name: French Polynesia
CountryData.description: French Polynesia is an overseas collectivity of France in the South Pacific Ocean. It’s comprised of 118 islands, of which 67 are inhabited. Known for its stunning turquoise lagoons, volcanic peaks, and vibrant coral reefs, it’s a tropical paradise attracting tourists and researchers alike. The islands boast a unique blend of Polynesian and French cultures, reflected in its cuisine, traditions, and architecture.

quickFacts.label: Population
quickFacts.description: The total population of French Polynesia is approximately 306,838, spread across its numerous islands.
quickFacts.detail: The population density is relatively low, with most residents concentrated on Tahiti and its surrounding islands.

quickFacts.label: Area
quickFacts.description: French Polynesia covers a total area of 4,039 square kilometers (1,558 square miles).
quickFacts.detail: This includes land and marine areas, highlighting the vastness of its oceanic territory.

quickFacts.label: Capital
quickFacts.description: Papeete is the capital and largest city of French Polynesia, located on the island of Tahiti.
quickFacts.detail: It serves as the administrative, economic, and cultural center of the collectivity.

quickFacts.label: Currency
quickFacts.description: The official currency of French Polynesia is the CFP Franc (XPF).
quickFacts.detail: It is pegged to the Euro and the US Dollar.

quickFacts.label: Language
quickFacts.description: French is the official language, while Tahitian is widely spoken and holds significant cultural importance.
quickFacts.detail: Many residents also speak English, particularly in tourist areas.

quickFacts.label: GDP
quickFacts.description: The Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of French Polynesia in 2022 was approximately $6.3 billion.
quickFacts.detail: Tourism is the dominant contributor to the economy.

climateData.title: Tropical Climate
climateData.description: French Polynesia enjoys a classic tropical climate characterized by consistently warm temperatures and high humidity throughout the year. Rainfall is generally abundant, particularly during the wet season, but the islands are also blessed with plenty of sunshine.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Summer (December - April)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Summer brings the warmest temperatures and the highest rainfall. It’s a lush and vibrant time of year, ideal for exploring the islands’ interior and enjoying water activities.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Autumn (May - September)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Autumn marks a transition period with decreasing rainfall and slightly cooler temperatures. The seas are calmer, making it a good time for sailing and exploring the outer islands.

seasonalCharacteristics.name: Winter (October - November)
seasonalCharacteristics.description: Winter is considered the dry season, with the least rainfall and the most sunshine. It’s a popular time to visit, offering ideal conditions for outdoor activities.

naturalWonders.name: The Tuamotu Archipelago
naturalWonders.description: The Tuamotus are a stunning chain of coral atolls stretching across the South Pacific. These remote islands offer unparalleled beauty, pristine beaches, and exceptional diving and snorkeling opportunities.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: Comprising over 70 islands, many uninhabited, the Tuamotus are a vital part of French Polynesia’s ecosystem. They are renowned for their vibrant coral reefs, abundant marine life, and traditional Polynesian culture.

naturalWonders.name: Mount Orohena
naturalWonders.description: Mount Orohena, located on the island of Tahiti, is the highest point in French Polynesia, offering breathtaking panoramic views of the surrounding landscape.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: This dormant volcano is a significant landmark and a popular hiking destination. Its slopes are covered in lush rainforest, providing habitat for a diverse range of flora and fauna.
viewingTips: Check weather conditions before heading out

naturalWonders.name: Raiatea
naturalWonders.description: Raiatea is considered the sacred island of French Polynesia, holding immense cultural and historical significance as the origin point of the Polynesian civilization.
naturalWonders.detailedDescription: It’s home to the Taputapuatea marae, a UNESCO World Heritage site, and a testament to the ancient Polynesian people’s sophisticated religious practices and architectural skills. The island’s interior is dominated by Mount Puia, an active volcano.
viewingTips: Learn about the island’s history and culture

ecosystemData.title: Polynesian Ecosystems
ecosystemData.overview: French Polynesia boasts a remarkably diverse ecosystem, encompassing coral reefs, volcanic mountains, rainforests, and coastal wetlands. This biodiversity is a result of the islands’ unique geological history and isolation.

biodiversityCategories.name: Coral Reefs
biodiversityCategories.description: French Polynesia’s coral reefs are among the most vibrant and diverse in the world, supporting a vast array of marine life.

notableSpecies.name: Manta Ray
notableSpecies.significance: A keystone species in the reef ecosystem

biodiversityCategories.name: Rainforests
biodiversityCategories.description: The interior of many islands is covered in lush rainforests, home to a wealth of endemic plant and animal species.

notableSpecies.name: Moa Henna
notableSpecies.significance: A flightless bird unique to French Polynesia

notableSpecies.name: Tahitian Parakeet
notableSpecies.significance: An iconic symbol of the islands

activities.title: Outdoor Adventures
activities.description: French Polynesia offers a wide range of outdoor activities for all interests and skill levels, from thrilling water sports to challenging hikes.

activityCategories.name: Hiking
activityCategories.description: Explore the islands’ volcanic peaks, lush rainforests, and coastal trails.

activities.name: Mount Puia Hike
activities.description: A challenging hike to the summit of Mount Puia, offering stunning views of Raiatea.

activities.name: Tahitian Trail Hike
activities.description: A scenic hike through the rainforests of Tahiti.

activityCategories.name: Water Sports
activityCategories.description: Experience the crystal-clear waters of French Polynesia with a variety of water sports.

activities.name: Scuba Diving
activities.description: Explore the vibrant coral reefs and abundant marine life.

activities.name: Surfing
activities.description: Catch the waves at some of the world’s best surf breaks.

clothing.winter: Layers of clothing, waterproof jacket, sweater, long pants

equipment.basic: Sunglasses, insect repellent, reusable water bottle
